intro: Anemia phyllitidis var. tweedieana, commonly known as the Tweedie's anemia plant, is a rare and specialized species belonging to the family Apiaceae. It is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves that are often covered in a dense layer of fine hairs. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as along stream banks or in woodland areas. Its flowers are small and clustered in umbels, a common feature among members of the carrot family. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a botanically intriguing but endangered species.
